title: Devils notes: Hynes doesn't use coach's challenge on disallowed goal - Hockey
text:
No challenge 
Devils coach John Hynes opted not to utilize the NHL’s new coach’s challenge when an apparent short-handed rebound goal by Jacob Josefson with 48.5 seconds remaining in the second period was disallowed because Stephen Gionta had made contact with goaltender Martin Jones in the crease. Gionta had driven hard to the net off the left wing to take the initial shot and bumped into Jones near the left post before Josefson put in the rebound.
Under the NHL’s new rule, coaches can ask for a video review on goals that are disallowed for goaltender interference, but the Devils’ video staff reviewed the play and relayed down to the bench that it was not worth the challenge, which would have cost Hynes his timeout.
"There’s contact with the goaltender in the crease without being pushed in, so the way the rule is written – we reviewed it, our guys upstairs reviewed it – it was a situation where it was the right call on the ice," Hynes said.
Zajac sidelined 
Although Travis Zajac had missed practice the previous two days because of a nagging lower-body injury, the Devils had expected the 30-year-old center to be OK to play against the Sharks on Friday, but, after he still didn’t feel right at the morning skate, decided to hold him out.
"I didn’t think it would be smart [to play]," Zajac said. "It didn’t feel as good as I thought it would after a couple days of rest. So, I’ll take another day and, hopefully, that helps."
Briefs 
LW Stefan Matteau was the Devils’ lone healthy scratch up front. ... With John Moore returning after missing Tuesday’s 3-1 loss to Nashville with a bruised right forearm, D Eric Gelinas was pushed out of the lineup.
— Tom Gulitti
